strategic_profile.executive_summary: Marquette University is a private Catholic Jesuit research university in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, offering a comprehensive range of undergraduate and graduate programs. It emphasizes critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and service to others, preparing students for diverse paths and significant positive impact in the world.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Holistic review, considering academic achievement alongside unique talents, leadership and service activities, application essay, school profile, letters of recommendation, and optional test scores.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Marquette University is categorized as 'more selective' with an acceptance rate of 87.2% for the Class of 2026, and offers a test-optional policy for admissions.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants should focus on a strong academic record, compelling essays, and demonstrating leadership and service, as test scores are optional and part of a holistic review.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Marquette ranks highly for job placement, being 6th nationally 10 years after graduation according to Zippia.com, and is recognized for best salaries for graduates by the WSJ/College Pulse 2026 rankings.
analyst_takeaways.implication: The university provides strong career prospects and a good return on investment for its graduates, suggesting a robust connection to post-graduation employment.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Marquette emphasizes community service and service-learning, ranking 1st for 'Most Engaged in Community Service' by The Princeton Review's 2026 rankings.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Students interested in social justice and community involvement will find a supportive environment and numerous opportunities to engage in meaningful service.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Marquette offers a vibrant and engaging campus life with over 270 student organizations, promoting academic and personal growth within an urban environment that still maintains a distinct campus feel. There is a strong sense of community and emphasis on giving back through service. Housing options range from traditional residence halls for freshmen to suite-style accommodations and off-campus apartments for upperclassmen.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: The urban location in Milwaukee provides convenient access to public transportation, with many city bus routes crossing through campus and a discounted U-PASS available for students. Marquette also offers a free EagleExpress transportation service for nighttime safety and transports to Amtrak and Greyhound. While public transit is available, some students report infrequent usage for work or school due to concerns about bus frequency, reliability, and personal security, often opting for personal vehicles or rideshare services for time-sensitive commitments.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Marquette is actively growing its research activity, evidenced by a 52% increase in research and development expenditures and a 70% increase in R01 awards from NIH over five years. More than 1 in 4 undergraduates participate in faculty-led research across all colleges, with opportunities for corporate sponsored research, collaborations with business and civic partners, and innovative experiences through initiatives like the 707 Hub. The university is recognized as a 'Most Innovative University' by U.S. News & World Report.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Applications surpassed 20,000, a more than 30% increase over two years from Fall 2023. Data for applications, admits, and enrolled, and associated in-state/out-of-state/international breakdowns are from the Common Data Set 2025-2026. Waitlist data also from CDS 2025-2026.

Acceptance rate of 81.3% is consistent across multiple sources. Enrollment figure of 2,148 from College Raptor. Waitlist data from Clastify and Common Data Set 2024-2025 template for ranked status. Clastify specifically mentions '452 students were offered admission, yielding a 25% acceptance rate with 113 students accepted,' implying 452 accepted spots.

Applications, admitted, and overall acceptance rate from Data USA. Enrolled total is the incoming first-year class. Waitlist offered spots and accepted spots from Common Data Set 2023-2024. Admitted from waitlist calculated based on 35% acceptance rate reported by Clastify (200 * 0.35). Waitlist is unranked according to CDS 2023-2024.

Applications, admitted, enrolled, and acceptance rate from Wikipedia. Waitlist data from Common Data Set 2022-2023. The calculated waitlist admit rate matches Clastify's reported 48.8%. Waitlist is unranked according to CDS 2022-2023.

Applications, admitted, and enrolled from College Factual, also consistent with CDS 2021-2022 figures. Acceptance rate confirmed by Clastify. Waitlist data from Common Data Set 2021-2022. The calculated waitlist admit rate matches Clastify's reported 19%. Waitlist is unranked according to CDS 2021-2022.

Applications, admitted, and enrolled derived from combined men and women totals in Common Data Set 2020-2021. Acceptance rate confirmed by Clastify. Waitlist data from Common Data Set 2020-2021. Waitlist is unranked according to CDS 2020-2021.

gpa.notes: Average weighted GPA for admitted students is 3.6, with a middle 50% range of 3.5-3.7. The average unweighted GPA is 3.3, with a middle 50% range of 3.2-3.4.

testing.policy_note: Test-optional policy; standardized test scores are considered if submitted.

men.note: For first-time, first-year degree-seeking freshmen, Fall 2022.

women.note: For first-time, first-year degree-seeking freshmen, Fall 2022.

colleges.name: Klingler College of Arts and Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for intellectually curious students seeking a broad liberal arts education with flexible major and minor options. Strong emphasis on critical thinking and problem-solving within a Jesuit framework.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional residence halls with a strong community feel, offering general communal and study spaces. Living Learning Communities are available across campus for themed engagement.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious, open-minded, community-oriented, engaged in diverse subjects.

majors.notes: Internal transfers to the College of Business Administration are competitive and reviewed twice a year (Dec 1 for Spring, May 1 for Fall). Requires a minimum C or higher in all major requirements and electives, including core introductory courses.

majors.name: Biomedical Engineering
prerequisite_courses: PHYS 1003 General Physics with Introductory Calculus I
weeder_courses: PHYS 1003 General Physics with Introductory Calculus I
majors.notes: Internal transfer into the College of Engineering requires a minimum 2.750 cumulative GPA and grades of B- or higher in MATH 1450 Calculus 1 and PHYS 1003 General Physics with Introductory Calculus 1 or equivalent courses. Offers concentrations in Biocomputing, Bioelectronics, and Biomechanics.

Students may elect a major in either Civil Engineering or Environmental Engineering.

colleges.name: College of Health Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Highly competitive, especially for direct-entry professional programs like Physical Therapy. Requires strong academic performance in science and a passion for healthcare and patient well-being.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional residence halls with a strong community feel, offering general communal and study spaces. Living Learning Communities are available across campus for themed engagement.
colleges.student_archetype: Dedicated to service, scientifically adept, compassionate, driven to improve health outcomes.

weeder_courses: BISC 2015 Principles of Human Anatomy & Physiology I
majors.special_requirements: Strong academic credentials are expected. Option for 3+3 Early Assurance PharmD program with MCW.
majors.notes: Internal transfer policies for College of Health Sciences are not explicitly detailed, but students are encouraged to contact advisors. This major is often a pathway for pre-health professions. Disciplinary Honors is available.

prerequisite_courses: SPPA 1001 Introduction to Speech Pathology and Audiology
majors.notes: Internal transfer policies for College of Health Sciences are not explicitly detailed.

colleges.name: College of Nursing
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: For empathetic and detail-oriented individuals committed to direct patient care and making a difference in the healthcare field. Strong science background is beneficial.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional residence halls with a strong community feel, offering general communal and study spaces. Living Learning Communities are available across campus for themed engagement.
colleges.student_archetype: Caring, resilient, service-oriented, precise, with a strong commitment to patient advocacy.

majors.name: Nursing
prerequisite_courses: BISC 2015 Principles of Human Anatomy & Physiology I
BISC 2016 Principles of Human Anatomy & Physiology II
PSYC 2101 Introduction to Life-Span Developmental Psychology
weeder_courses: BISC 2015 Principles of Human Anatomy & Physiology I
majors.special_requirements: Direct entry program, guarantees required classes and clinical hours upon admission. Clinical enrollment requires physical exam, CPR/BLS certification, and criminal background checks.
majors.notes: Internal transfers are highly competitive, reviewed twice a year (Dec 1 for Spring, May 1 for Fall), and only a limited number are accepted. Students transferring into the sophomore cohort for a three-year graduation plan must have HEAL 1060, BISC 2015 & 2016 completed at time of enrollment. Minimum 2.500 cumulative GPA required for the degree.

minors_certificates: Arabic Language and Culture Studies Minor

application_deadlines.notes: Non-binding commitment; decision by late December
Decision by March 1. Applications after this date reviewed on rolling, space-available basis.

supplemental_requirements.details: An essay or personal statement is required for all first-year applicants.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Accelerated Doctor of Physical Therapy Program
supplemental_requirements.details: Required essay on interest in physical therapy and relevant experiences.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Accelerated Doctor of Occupational Therapy Program
supplemental_requirements.details: Required essay on interest in occupational therapy and relevant experiences.
Required essay on interest in athletic training and relevant experiences.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Emphasis on alignment with Marquette's Jesuit mission, valuing service, social justice, leadership, and integrity.

major_selection_tactics: Apply to a less competitive major if not fully committed to highly competitive fields like Computer Science or Engineering, as some colleges within Marquette are significantly more competitive for admission.
Consider applying as 'undeclared' within the College of Letters and Science to gain admission flexibility and time to explore interests before declaring a specific major.
Research major-specific admission rates or competitiveness before applying, as some programs (e.g., Engineering, Health Sciences, Nursing) have higher barriers to entry.
Take challenging courses in high school and be actively involved in extracurricular activities and volunteering to strengthen your overall application.
Investigate programs Marquette is particularly known for, such as the Civil and Environmental Engineering program, which has received strong recommendations.
college_ranking_tactics: Rank colleges not solely on overall prestige but also on factors like general education (GE) requirements and how they align with your academic goals.
Consider the quality and social environment of on-campus housing options, as dorm life is a significant part of the freshman experience at Marquette.
Evaluate the strength of the alumni network and job placement rates for your desired field, as Marquette is noted for strong alumni connections and job prospects.
Assess the surrounding neighborhood for safety, walkability, and access to public transportation when considering off-campus living or campus environment.
Factor in the school spirit and social aspects, such as engagement with athletics, as these can heavily influence the overall college experience.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If applying to a competitive major (e.g., Computer Science in Engineering), list a backup major in a different college, such as Cognitive Science in the College of Letters and Science. Marquette's application allows for two college choices, and it is generally easier to transfer between colleges after admission (except for Nursing), potentially increasing your chances of acceptance to the university.

scholarships.name: Marquette University Merit Scholarships (Pre Marquette Award)
Michael R. Lovell Presidential Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Full tuition, fees, housing, and food
scholarships.benefits: Faculty mentor, experiential learning, University Honors Program, guaranteed Honors summer research or creative project fellowship, $1000 Honors study-abroad award

scholarships.name: Burke Scholars Program
scholarships.amount: Full tuition, fees, housing, and food
scholarships.benefits: Stipend for living expenses (need-based), weekly community service (10 hours/week), seminars, leadership development, peer and staff support, extracurricular activities

scholarships.name: Urban Scholars Program
scholarships.benefits: Holistic advising, leadership and professional development, community engagement, socio-cultural activities; housing scholarships sometimes offered or Federal Pell Grant can be applied to housing/food

scholarships.name: J. William and Mary Diederich Scholarship
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for four years for students in the Diederich College of Communication
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration (by applying for admission to the Diederich College of Communication)

scholarships.name: Opus Scholars Program
scholarships.amount: Full tuition, fees, on-campus housing, and food
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for four years for students in the Opus College of Engineering, support and programming for engineering scholars
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration (by applying for admission to the Opus College of Engineering and completing FAFSA)

scholarships.name: National Merit Scholarship
scholarships.benefits: Additive to any other Marquette-sponsored scholarship, can exceed full tuition
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration (for National Merit Finalists who indicate Marquette as first-choice)

ap_policy.general_rule: Score of 3+ grants credit for most exams, although specific scores and course equivalencies are determined by faculty review and outlined in an official chart.
exceptions: Pre-med and pre-dent students should consult a pre-health adviser before accepting AP credit awards
Credit for physics does not include lab credit; labs must be completed at Marquette for science and engineering majors
ap_policy.usage: Can satisfy general education requirements; students are encouraged to consult with departments before registering for advanced courses

ib_policy.general_rule: HL exams with scores of 4+ generally grant credit; specific SL exams like Mathematics: Analysis and Approaches and Mathematics: Analysis and Interpretations require a score of 7 for credit.

transfer_articulation.restrictions: A minimum of 45 degree credits must be earned at Marquette, with the final 30 credits for the degree earned at Marquette or through an approved study abroad program. Transferred credits with a grade less than C only apply to requirements that do not require a C or better.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework, including AP/IB classes, while maintaining good grades.
Demonstrated interest and aptitude in your chosen major, especially for popular programs like nursing or business, through coursework and extracurriculars.
Alignment with Marquette's Jesuit values such as leadership, service, and integrity.
An upward trajectory in grades throughout high school, showing a desire to grow and improve.
Submitting competitive SAT/ACT scores, though test-optional, as most applicants do.
common_activities: Leadership positions in school clubs and organizations.
Research experience, as nearly all students participate in some form during their undergraduate experience.
Involvement in campus activities, including club sports and Greek life.
essay_tips: Be specific about why Marquette, connecting your interests and goals to what the university offers.
Show, don't tell, using personal experiences to illustrate your passion and understanding of your chosen field.
Let your personality shine and be authentic, demonstrating why you would be a good fit for the Marquette community.
Implicitly show how you embody Marquette's motto, 'Be the Difference'.

For special programs (e.g., Physical Therapy, Occupational Therapy), clearly articulate what sparked your interest, how you've explored it, your future goals, and how Marquette will help you achieve them.
red_flags: Significant grade decline senior year, though some leniency may be shown for a single challenging class if other grades are decent.
Generic essays that could apply to any university and don't demonstrate specific interest in Marquette.
Not challenging oneself with a rigorous academic schedule when capable.
Missing application deadlines, particularly for early action or scholarships.
Failing to proofread for spelling and grammar mistakes.
insights: Marquette has a holistic admission review process, considering academic achievement alongside unique talents, leadership, service, and the application essay.
Applying Early Action is highly recommended as it shows strong interest and results in an earlier decision.
The university values students who can contribute positively to its private, Catholic institution community, emphasizing Jesuit values.
Many students appreciate the supportive faculty and resources available to help them succeed.
Marquette's direct admission programs for certain fields (e.g., Physical Therapy) are highly competitive and should be applied for as a freshman.
